2001
2009 }} '''George Dario Marino Franchitti'''{{cite news |url=http://www.hondanews.com/categories/1150/releases/3961 |title=Andretti Green Racing Team Profile |publisher=[[Acura]] |date=3 January 2007 |accessdate=2008-12-02}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/1697991.stm |title=Second star wedding for Highland town |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=7 December 2001 |accessdate=2008-12-02}} (born 19 May 1973) is a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[race car|racing]] driver. He formerly competed in the [[Champ Car|CART]] series before switching to the [[Indy Racing League|IndyCar Series]] where he was 2007 champion, and won the rain-shortened [[2007 Indianapolis 500]]. Franchitti is also a former [[NASCAR]] driver for [[Chip Ganassi Racing]], competing until mid-2008 when his team shut down.{{cite news | title = Lack of sponsorship forces Ganassi to shut down Franchitti's team | publisher = [[ESPN]]| url =http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=3469675| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} Franchitti returned to the IndyCar Series for the 2009 season, driving the #10 [[Target Corporation|Target]] [[Honda]]/[[Dallara]] for Target Chip Ganassi Racing.{{cite news | title = Franchitti in, Wheldon out at Target Chip Ganassi Racing | publisher = [[Yahoo]]| url =http://sports.yahoo.com/nascar/news?slug=txganassifranchitti&prov=st&type=lgns| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} He is the current, four-time IndyCar Series champion after claiming a third title in 2010 and fourth title in 2011 in addition to his 2007 and 2009 titles. On 30 May 2010, he won his second [[2010 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]] race. He is the second driver in Indycar series history to take four titles in four consecutive series of racing, after SÃ©bastien Bourdais, after accounting for his 2008 absence from the series. He also competed in the [[American Le Mans Series]] for Andretti Green Racing with his brother [[Marino Franchitti|Marino]] and former IndyCar Series teammate [[Bryan Herta]]. He won the 2007 [[BBC Scotland]] Sports Personality of the Year award. Franchitti was born in [[Bathgate]], [[West Lothian]], Scotland. == Career History == ===Early career=== While attending [[Stewart's Melville College]] in [[Edinburgh, Scotland|Edinburgh]], Franchitti became interested in karting. [[Allan McNish]] credited a large part of the start given to himself, Franchitti and [[David Coulthard]] as being down to [[David Leslie (racing driver)|David Leslie]] senior and junior.[http://qosfc.com/HeadlineNews/ViewFullStory/tabid/151/selectmoduleid/498/ArticleID/842/reftab/36/Default.aspx Allan McNish interview part 2 on qosfc.com] Franchitti won the Karting Scottish Junior Championship in 1984, the British Junior Championships in 1985 and 1986 and the Scottish senior title in 1988. He progressed to [[Formula Opel|Formula Vauxhall Junior]] where he won the championship with four victories in 1991. He moved up to Formula Vauxhall Lotus in 1992, where he joined [[Paul Stewart Racing]]. In his first year, he finished fourth in the overall championship, and was named the [[McLaren Autosport BRDC Award|McLaren/Autosport Young Driver of the Year]]. Staying with the team for the next season, he won the championship in 1993. He graduated to the [[British Formula Three Championship]] in [[1994 British Formula Three season|1994]], where he finished fourth and won one race in his first year. However, he was not retained for 1995 which was his final year in single-seaters in Europe. Instead, Franchitti was contracted by [[Mercedes-AMG|AMG Racing]] to drive a works [[Mercedes C-Class]] in the [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Meisterschaft|German Touring Car Championship]] and the related International Touring Car Championship, where he finished fifth and third respectively. He continued in the ITC in 1996, finishing fourth overall with one race win. Franchitti performed test driver duties for the [[Jaguar racing|Jaguar F1]] team under his mentor [[Jackie Stewart]] in the [[2000 Formula One season]], but was not able to secure a drive in the World Championship. === CART === [[File:FranchittiCar.JPG|right|thumb||Dario's car being pushed up to qualify for the [[2006 Indianapolis 500]].]] With the demise of the ITC, Mercedes placed Franchitti in [[Hogan Racing]] in [[1997 CART season|1997]], making his US debut in the [[Champ Car|PPG/CART Champ Car World Series]] where his best finish was a ninth at [[1997 Sunbelt IndyCarnival|Surfers Paradise]]. In [[1998 CART season|1998]] he joined [[Team Green]] (forerunner to the current [[Andretti Green Racing]]), finishing third in the season standings with three wins (his first coming at [[Champ Car Grand Prix of Road America|Road America]]) and a season-high five [[pole positions]]. Franchitti finished runner-up in the [[1999 CART season]] behind rookie [[Juan Pablo Montoya]]. Both drivers scored 212 points, but Montoya had seven wins to Franchitti's three and was crowned champion. Franchitti's close friend [[Greg Moore (race car driver)|Greg Moore]] died in a crash during [[1999 Marlboro 500|the final race of the year]] at [[Auto Club Speedway|California Speedway]] in [[Fontana, California]]. A heavy crash in pre-season testing the next year ruined Franchitti's [[2000 CART season|2000 season]], and he only won once at [[Grand Prix of Cleveland|Cleveland]] in [[2001 CART season|2001]]. In [[2002 CART season|2002]] he won the [[Vancouver Molson Indy]]. He dedicated his win to Greg Moore, who was killed in 1999 and was from [[Vancouver, British Columbia]]. He finished fourth in Champ Car in 2002. ==IndyCar Series== {{Infobox former Champ Car driver| name = | nationality = {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Scottish people|British]] |Years = [[1997 CART season|1997]] â [[2007 IndyCar Series season|2007]], [[2009 IndyCar Series season|2009]] â [[2010 IndyCar Series season|2010]] | Team(s) = Hogan Racing ([[1997 CART season|1997]]), [[Andretti Green Racing|Team KOOL Green]] ([[1998 CART season|1998]]â[[2002 CART season|2002]]), [[Andretti Green Racing]] ([[2003 IndyCar Series season|2003]]â[[2007 IndyCar Series season|2007]])

[[File:DarioFranchittiMay2007Practice.jpg|thumb|right|Practicing for the [[2007 Indianapolis 500|2007 Indy 500]].]] ===2003=== Franchitti moved with the Andretti Green team to the [[Indy Racing League|IndyCar Series]] in [[2003 IndyCar Series season|2003]] but his season was ended by a back injury sustained in a [[motorcycle]] accident while on holiday in Scotland.{{cite news | title = Scot Dario becomes an American idol | publisher = [[BBC Sport]]| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/6700913.stm| accessdate = 2009-07-15 | date=29 May 2007}}{{cite news | title = Franchitti injured in bike crash| publisher = [[The Scotsman|Scotsman]]| url = http://sport.scotsman.com/motorbikes/Franchitti-injured-in-bike-crash.2417267.jp| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} Franchitti missed most of the year, and his place was taken by [[Dan Wheldon]] at [[Twin Ring Motegi|Motegi]],{{cite news | title = Franchitti injured in motorbike crash| publisher = GrandPrix.com| url = http://www.gpmag.com/ns/ns10978.html| accessdate = 2009-07-20}} [[Robby Gordon]] at [[2003 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis]],{{cite news | title = Sports Round-up | publisher = Telegraph| url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2401135/Sports-Round-up.html| accessdate = 2009-07-20 | location=London | date=8 May 2003}} and [[Bryan Herta]] for the remainder of the year (with Wheldon taking over a regular role from retiring team boss [[Michael Andretti]]). ===2004=== Franchitti returned to the cockpit in [[2004 IndyCar Series season|2004]], and won his first IRL IndyCar Series race on 25 July at the [[Milwaukee Mile]].{{cite news | title = First IRL victory thrills Franchitti| publisher = [[ESPN]]| url = http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1846330| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} He followed this win up with a win at [[Pikes Peak International Raceway|Pikes Peak]] on 22 August.{{cite news | title = Franchitti gets second win; Rice has disaster| publisher = [[ESPN]]| url = http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=1865293&type=story| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} ===2005=== Franchitti returned to Andretti Green Racing again, and had 2 wins. The first win came at [[Nashville Superspeedway|Nashville]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti feels right at home, wins in Nashville| publisher = [[CBS Sports]]| url = http://www.cbssports.com/autoracing/story/8651402/1| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} His last win of the year came at the [[2005 IndyCar Series season|2005 season]] finale at [[California Speedway|California]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti Leads Honda Sweep of Fontana Finale| publisher = [[Honda]]| url = http://world.honda.com/INDY/2005/17california/race/| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} ===2007=== On 3 January 2007, Andretti Green Racing announced that Franchitti had re-signed for the IRL team for a tenth consecutive season in [[American Championship Car Racing|American Open Wheel racing]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti back with Andretti Green Racing for 2007| publisher = [[USA Today]]| url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/irl/2007-01-03-franchitti-andretti_x.htm| accessdate = 2009-07-15 | date=3 January 2007}} [[2007 American Le Mans Series season|That year]] he also undertook a limited programme in the [[American Le Mans Series]] driving an [[Acura ARX-01]], teaming up with his younger brother, [[Marino Franchitti]] and long-time AGR team-mate [[Bryan Herta]].{{cite news | title = The Franchitti factor | publisher = [[IndyCar Series|Indycar]]| url = http://www.indycar.com/news/story.php?story_id=7992| accessdate = 2009-07-20}} On 27 May 2007, Franchitti won a [[Rainout (sports)|rain-shortened]] [[2007 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]], finishing under a yellow flag after an accident involving [[Dan Wheldon]] and [[Marco Andretti]] following lap 163. The race was halted due to rain three laps later. His prize money of $1.6m was equal to the entire purse for the [[1982 Indianapolis 500|1982 race]]. During the [[2007 IndyCar Series season|2007 season]], Franchitti survived two huge crashes which saw his car flip upside down both times. The first at [[2007 Firestone Indy 400|Michigan]] saw him tangle with [[Dan Wheldon]] resulting in his car flipping before being hit again by [[Scott Dixon]]. The contact with Dixon was only inches away from his head and the accident saw seven cars (including Franchitti) retire from the race. The second flip came a week later at [[2007 Meijer Indy 300|Kentucky]]. As Franchitti crossed the start/finish line to finish the race, the [[Scotland|Scotsman]] who had not realised the chequered flag had been waved continued to race and crashed into the back of [[Kosuke Matsuura]] flipping yet again and hitting the outside wall. Franchitti took full responsibility for the incident. Franchitti won the IndyCar Championship with four wins finishing ahead of [[Scott Dixon]] by just 13 points. Dixon ran out of fuel on the last lap of [[2007 Peak Antifreeze Indy 300|the season-ending race]], allowing Franchitti to take the win and the championship, his first championship win since Formula Vauxhall Lotus in 1993. Franchitti returned to the IndyCar series for [[2009 IndyCar Series season|2009]] in the [[Target Corporation|Target]] [[Chip Ganassi Racing]] #10 car, replacing [[Dan Wheldon]] who moved to [[Panther Racing]]. He debuted for the team in the [[2008 Nikon Indy 300|non points race at Surfers Paradise]] in [[Australia]] on 25 October 2008. He qualified 4th of 24 drivers and was running third when he spun and stalled the car, resulting in a lap-down finish of 16th. He led 2 laps and set the [[fastest lap]] of the race. ===2008=== Franchitti missed the 2008 Indianapolis 500 as he pursued a NASCAR career. He rejoined the IndyCar Series in 2009 with Target Ganassi Racing and went on to win his second and third IndyCar titles in 2009 and 2010. ===2009=== 2009 marked a successful return to Indycar for Dario scooping five wins, two second and two third placings and taking the series championship in his second consecutive attempt over teammate Scott Dixon by 11 points. ===2010=== Franchitti got off to a steady if unspectacular start; through the first 5 races, Dario had 1 pole, 3 Top 5 finishes and 4 Top 10s. However, at the [[2010 Indianapolis 500|94th]] running of the [[Indianapolis 500]], it all came together for him. Starting on the outside of the first row (#3), Franchitti had the best car of the day, leading over 150 laps to take his 2nd win in the past four years. This is also his 24th win in American Open-wheel driving, placing him in the top 20 all-time. The win also makes him the 18th multiple-win driver in the history of the [[Indianapolis 500]].{{Cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/racing/indycar/news/story?id=5234215|title=Franchitti wins Indianapolis 500|date=31 May 2010|work=[[ESPN.com]]|publisher=[[ESPN]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|location=[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]], [[Speedway, Indiana]]|accessdate=2010-05-31}} In October, Franchitti will travel to Australia to compete in a special round of the V8 Supercar championship in which he and 17 other international drivers will pair up with regular V8 drivers in two {{convert|300|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} endurance races at the Gold Coast Street Circuit, a former venue for Indycar. He will drive for Jim Beam Racing with Steve Johnson. By finishing eighth in the 2010 Izod Indycar series championship final at the Homestead Miami Speedway, and leading the most laps on top of qualifying in pole position, Dario overhauled Will Power's 12 points lead and took the 2010 Izod Indycar championship. In effect Dario had won all of the past three championships he entered when his 2008 absence is accounted for. ===2011=== Franchitti, again driving for Target Chip Ganassi Racing, won the season opening road race at St. Petersburg, Florida. He followed that win with additional wins at Texas Motor Speedway (28th victory). He took the pole and the win in the [[Milwaukee 225]] for his 29th victory, tying him with [[Rick Mears]] for 9th all-time in American Open Wheel racing. At the final race of the season in [[IZOD IndyCar World Championships|Las Vegas]], a 15 car crash on lap 12 caused the race to be red flagged. After two hours of red flag, IndyCar CEO [[Randy Bernard]] announced the death of [[Dan Wheldon]], and the race was formally ended. The drivers who were able to do so participated in a 5 lap tribute to Wheldon 10 minutes after the announcement.[http://www.tsn.ca/auto_racing/story/?id=378250 Dan Wheldon dies in crash at Las Vegas Indy 300] Because the race was canceled, Franchitti â who entered the race with an 18-point lead over Power in the title standingsâ won his third consecutive IndyCar championship and fourth overall. ==NASCAR== [[File:Dario Franchitti at Homestead-Miami.jpg|thumb|left|Dario Franchitti racing in the 2007 Ford 300 at the Homestead-Miami Speedway.]] [[File:Dario Franchitti 2008 Daytona.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Franchitti at Daytona in 2008]] On 3 October 2007, it was announced that Franchitti would move to NASCAR to replace [[David Stremme]] in the #40 [[Fastenal]] [[Dodge]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti announced as Chip Ganassi's NASCAR driver | publisher = [[Yahoo]]| url =http://sports.yahoo.com/nascar/news?slug=txfranchittinascar&prov=st&type=lgns| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} He made his [[stock car]] debut in the [[ARCA RE/MAX Series]] on 5 October at [[Talladega Superspeedway]], qualifying 6th and finishing 17th in the #42 [[Target Corporation|Target]] [[Dodge Charger (LX)|Dodge Charger]] for [[Chip Ganassi Racing]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti finishes 17th on ARCA debut | publisher = [[Autosport]]| url =http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/63052| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} His move to stock cars had similarities to former CART rival [[Juan Pablo Montoya]]'s move from [[Formula One]] to [[NASCAR]] in 2006. Franchitti made his first [[NASCAR]] start on 20 October 2007 in the [[Craftsman Truck Series]] race at [[Martinsville Speedway]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti retires on NASCAR debut | publisher = [[Autosport]]| url =http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/63513| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} He drove the #41 Target [[Dodge Ram]] truck, owned by [[Cunningham Motorsports]], with Brian Pattie from Chip Ganassi Racing serving as crew chief.[http://www.speedtv.com/articles/nascar/craftsman/40909/ Franchitti Enters Martinsville] He would finish 33rd after being plagued by problems with the rear of the car during the race. [[File:Dario Franchitti Dodge Journey Charger.jpg|thumb|right|2008 Sprint Cup car]] On 26 April 2008, Franchitti suffered a slight left ankle fracture in a hard crash with [[Larry Gunselman]] while competing in the [[Nationwide Series]] [[2008 NASCAR Nationwide Series#Aaron's 312|Aaron's 312]] race.{{cite news | title =Scots star Dario Franchitti escapes horror crash with broken ankle | publisher = [[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]| url =http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/motorsport-news/2008/04/28/scots-star-dario-franchitti-escapes-horror-crash-with-broken-ankle-86908-20397805/| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} [[David Stremme]], [[Ken Schrader]], [[Jeremy Mayfield]], and [[Sterling Marlin]] all filled in for him.{{cite news | title =Stremme will replace Franchitti for Talladega ride | publisher = [[USA Today]]| url =http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2008-04-27-stremme-franchitti_N.htm| accessdate = 2009-07-15 | first=Seth | last=Livingstone | date=28 April 2008}}{{cite news | title =Schrader to replace injured Franchitti at Richmond | publisher = [[The Sports Network|TSN]]| url =http://www.tsn.ca/auto_racing/story/?id=236232| accessdate = 2009-07-15}}{{cite news | title =Mayfield to drive No. 40 for injured Franchitti at Dover | publisher = [[NASCAR]]| url =http://www.nascar.com/2008/news/headlines/cup/05/28/dfranchitti.jmayfield.dover.sub/index.html?eref=/rss/news/headlines/cup| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} On 1 July 2008, Franchitti's #40 Sprint Cup team was disbanded by co-owner Chip Ganassi because of a lack of sponsorship. Franchitti was running 41st in points in the Sprint Cup series at the time, and Ganassi had been funding the team out of his own pocket. The entire #40 team was shut down, and 71 employees were released.{{cite news | title = Franchitti loses drive in Nascar| publisher = [[BBC Sport]]| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/7484716.stm| accessdate = 2009-07-15 | date=2 July 2008}} On 9 August 2008 Dario won his 1st ever NASCAR Nationwide Pole at Watkins Glen.{{cite news | title = Franchitti Takes Zippo 200 Pole | publisher = [[Watkins Glen International|Watkins Glen]]| url =http://www.theglen.com/Articles/2008/08/Franchitti-Takes-Zippo-200-Pole.aspx| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} ==Sports Car Racing== Dario is well known for combining partial Sports Car racing schedules during his IndyCar and [[NASCAR]] career. At the [[2007 12 Hours of Sebring]] he finished 1st in [[LMP2]] class at the [[2007 12 Hours of Sebring]] with Andretti Green Racing team-mates [[Bryan Herta]] and [[Tony Kanaan]]. They finished 2nd overall. He also participated in the [[2007 ALMS Grand Prix of Long Beach]] with Bryan Herta and they finished 6th.{{cite news | title = Herta, Franchitti: Green-flag stop stuffed us | publisher = Crash.net| url =http://www.crash.net/alms/news/134199/1/herta_franchitti_green-flag_stop_stuffed_us.html| accessdate = 2009-07-15}} He placed 18th in LMP2 class in the [[2007 American Le Mans Series season]] standings with 32 points. Prior to the [[2008 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series]], he joined Chip Ganassi Racing teammate [[Juan Pablo Montoya]], [[Scott Pruett]] and [[Memo Rojas]] and won the [[Rolex 24]] at Daytona in a [[Lexus]]-[[Riley Technologies|Riley]].{{cite news | title = Dario Franchitti wins Daytona 24 Hours title | publisher = Telegraph| url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2290181/Dario-Franchitti-wins-Daytona-24-Hours-title.html| accessdate = 2009-07-15 | location=London | first=Andrew | last=Cotton | date=28 January 2008}} That was the only race he participated in during the [[2008 Rolex Sports Car Series season]] and finished 42nd overall in [[Daytona Prototype]] class with 35 points. In the [[2008 Petit Le Mans]] he was a driver for [[Highcroft Racing]] with [[Scott Sharp]] and [[David Brabham]].{{cite news | title = Franchitti to enter Petit Le Mans | publisher = [[Autosport]]| url = http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/70691| accessdate = 2009-07-16}} They were the first retirement after only 16 laps. For the [[2009 Rolex 24 At Daytona]] he once again drove for Chip Ganassi Racing in a Lexus-Riley. He finished 5th overall with [[Scott Dixon]] and [[Alex Lloyd]]. He participated in the [[2009 12 Hours of Sebring]] for Highcroft Racing with Scott Sharp and David Brabham.{{cite news | title = Franchitti rejoins Highcroft for Sebring | publisher = [[Autosport]]| url =http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/72997| accessdate = 2009-07-16}} They finished 15th overall and were the first non-finishers. He returned to Highcroft Racing with Scott Sharp and David Brabham for the [[2009 Petit Le Mans]].{{cite news | title = ALMS: Franchitti Rejoins Highcroft For Petit Le Mans | publisher = [[Speed TV]]| url =http://auto-racing.speedtv.com/article/alms-franchitti-rejoins-highcroft-for-petit-le-mans/alms-franchitti-rejoins-highcroft-for-petit-le-mans| accessdate = 2009-10-12}} ==Personal life== [[File:DarioAndAshley.JPG|right|thumb||Franchitti relaxes at Indy with his wife, Ashley Judd, in 2007]] Franchitti married [[United States|American]] [[actress]] [[Ashley Judd]] in 2001, at [[Skibo Castle]] near [[Dornoch]], [[Scotland]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/1697991.stm |title=Second star wedding for Highland town |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=7 December 2001 |accessdate=2008-12-02}} They currently live near [[Franklin, Tennessee]], in the United States. They have no children. Originally from Bathgate, his [[Italian-Scots]] family moved to nearby [[Whitburn, West Lothian|Whitburn]] when he was eight years old. He is a former pupil of [[Stewart's Melville College]] and he supports [[Celtic Football Club]].{{cite news|title=Franchitti is a true American idol but his heart belongs to Glasgow|publisher=[[The Times]]|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article1851668.ece|accessdate=2009-07-15|location=London|first=Kevin|last=Eason|date=29 May 2007}} He lists some of his favourite [[television]] shows as ''[[Gavin & Stacey]]'', ''[[Shameless]]'' and ''[[Rab C. Nesbitt]]''.{{cite news|title=The west of Lothian question: An interview with Bathgates's hero Dario Franchitti|publisher=[[Scotland on Sunday]]|url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/motorsport/The-west-of-Lothian-question.4769123.jp|accessdate=2009-07-16}} [[Paul di Resta]], a racing driver, is a cousin of Franchitti. Di Resta is a current race driver for the [[Force India F1 Team]]. ==Media Appearances== Franchitti has appeared on several [[television shows]]. The list includes ''[[The Morning Show with Mike & Juliet]]'', ''[[Larry King Live]]'', ''[[Pardon the Interruption]]'', ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly]]'' [[Jim Rome is Burning]], and three times on ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''.http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1040029/ ==Simraceway Game Design== On 13 October 2011, 3 days before Franchittiâs bid for a fourth IZOD IndyCar Series title, it was announced that he would be joining fellow driver [[Dan Wheldon]] in developing the vehicle physics on Ignite Game Technologiesâ online auto racing game, [[Simraceway]]. A vintage car racing enthusiast, Franchitti will be focusing on ensuring the authenticity of the gameâs historic and vintage cars âItâs almost impossible to describe the feeling you get inside when youâre behind the wheel of an old race car but what I hope to be able to do is use my knowledge and experience to help the team at Simraceway replicate how it feels to drive,â IndyCar Champion Dario Franchitti Joins Simraceway(TM) Development Team. http://www.marketwatch.com/story/indycar-champion-dario-franchitti-joins-simracewaytm-development-team-2011-10-13. ==Motorsports Career Results== ===Touring Car Racing=== ====German Touring Car Championship==== {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align:center; width:590px" !colspan=45| [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Meisterschaft]] results |- !
